ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class also utilized breakout rooms.

There were recorded lecture videos created by the head of the course that overlapped with much of the instructor's live virtual lecture content. The main difference between the recorded and live lecture is that during live lecture, we could work on practice problems in groups.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I grew in my knowledge of Multivariable Calculus and became confident in my ability to employ the techniques I learned in class.
Besides learning the content of multi-variable calculus, I learned about how mathematical theorems are motivated and became more comfortable justifying an answer with such theorems.
I developed a basic understand of multivariable calculus, including important theorems within the subject and how to use them.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The instructor always provided good practice problems during class and gave us the opportunity to work on them in breakout rooms.

I think the class should just have recorded/live lectures with one lecturer, I don't think the discussions sections really added anything. I found all my learning was from the textbook and recorded videos. I feel like the assignments and tests cause students to have a thorough understanding of the subject.

The course is well-paced and aligns well with the textbook. Also, the recorded lecture videos by the head of the course were very helpful.

I think the reading quizzes could be a bit longer so that they can cover the readings more comprehensively and allow students to recover a few points.

Strengths; There is a good support system available for problem sets and exam reviews (course wide review sessions, many office hours, etc). 
Weaknesses: Teaching seems to vary greatly by section. The class is formatted so that you do textbook readings on a subject, watch videos on it, and take a quiz on it before it is ever mentioned in lecture, which makes it feel like you are having to teach yourself multivariable calculus (I felt this was slightly unfair, given that some students came into the class already having taken multivariable and some students have 0 experience with it.)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the breakout rooms succeeded, as they provided a convenient place to do practice and confer with peers. However, I think the instructor could utilize online tools such as graphing programs more effectively.

As stated earlier I found the discussion sections not helpful and rather just found my learning to be through the recorded videos and textbook reading. I don't think the discussion sections are necessary or added anything.

My instructor began the semester working through problems with pen and paper, but eventually switched to using Google Jamboard, which I thought was a useful change.

Participation was generally poor during class and perhaps could have been stimulated by 1) waiting longer for student responses so as not to set the precedent that the instructor will answer his own question, anyway, and 2) asking for responses from each group after we work for problems to as to increase accountability.

The online course page was very well organized and office hours were accessible despite being on Zoom. Zoom lectures made class participation more difficult, especially for those of us who didnt have great sections or professors.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this to anyone who needs to learn Multivariable Calculus.

Yes as it provides a good fundamental understanding of the subject, however, it's mostly just tedious work and requires studying although it's not very challenging just time-consuming. Also, the class can be learned through just the textbook, videos, and Ximera.

Yes - if you mastered single-variable calculus (Calc BC), you can do multi-variable calculus. The class expects you to have a strong hold on the math from single-variable calculus, but new concepts are explained well and follow from nicely from concepts/theorems in single-variable calculus.
For fun, absolutely not. If you need to get a multivariable calculus credit as a prereq, yes, but only if you make sure you get a good section.
